The morning sun cast long shadows across the manicured lawns of Richmond Hill Palace, where King Edmund Fairweather III stood at his bedroom window, gripping the silk curtains with trembling fingers. Below in the ornamental pond, a family of mallards glided serenely across the water's surface, their movements sending ripples that caught the light like scattered diamonds. What should have been a peaceful scene instead filled the monarch with a dread so profound that sweat beaded on his brow despite the cool autumn air.

It had begun three months ago during a state dinner with the Danish ambassador. A decorative centerpiece featuring carved wooden ducks had somehow triggered something primal within him—a fear so intense and irrational that he'd excused himself mid-conversation and spent the remainder of the evening locked in his private study. Since that mortifying evening, the phobia had only grown stronger, spreading like ivy across every aspect of his carefully ordered life.

Edmund's valet, Reginald, entered the chamber carrying the morning papers and a silver tray laden with Earl Grey tea and buttered scones. The elderly man had served three generations of Fairweather kings and possessed an uncanny ability to sense his master's moods before they fully manifested themselves.

"Your Majesty appears troubled this morning," Reginald observed, setting the tray on the mahogany side table with practiced precision. "Perhaps a round of golf might prove beneficial? The weather is quite agreeable, and I believe your caddy Marcus mentioned something about perfecting your sand wedge technique."

The suggestion of golf brought the first genuine smile to Edmund's lips in days. The sprawling eighteen-hole course at Richmond Hill represented one of the few places where he could find respite from the crushing weight of royal obligations and the ever-present anxiety that now plagued his waking hours. More importantly, it meant spending time with Marcus Hartwell, the young man whose easy laughter and unpretentious manner had become something of an anchor in Edmund's increasingly turbulent world.

"An excellent suggestion, Reginald. Please inform Marcus that we'll tee off at nine o'clock sharp." Edmund turned from the window, deliberately avoiding another glance at the pond below. "And see that the groundskeepers have cleared the course of any... waterfowl."

The older man's expression remained diplomatically neutral, though Edmund caught a flicker of something—concern, perhaps, or pity—in his weathered features. Word of the king's unusual affliction had inevitably spread throughout the palace staff, despite Edmund's efforts to maintain discretion. While most of his servants remained respectfully silent about their master's condition, he was acutely aware of the whispered conversations that ceased whenever he entered a room.

An hour later, Edmund found himself on the first tee, inhaling the familiar scents of freshly cut grass and morning dew. The golf course stretched before him like a verdant tapestry, its rolling hills and strategic sand traps designed by some long-forgotten Scottish master. Here, surrounded by the gentle undulations of perfectly maintained fairways, the king could almost forget about the weight of the crown and the growing chorus of critics who questioned his fitness to rule.

Marcus Hartwell approached with the golf bag slung over his shoulder, his sandy hair tousled by the breeze and his face brightened by that characteristic grin that never failed to lift Edmund's spirits. At twenty-eight, Marcus was nearly a decade younger than the king, with the lean build of someone who spent his days walking miles across challenging terrain. He'd been working as Edmund's personal caddy for two years now, ever since the previous caddy had retired to tend his garden in the Cotswolds.

"Lovely morning for a round, Your Majesty," Marcus said, beginning his ritual of cleaning and arranging the clubs with the methodical care of a surgeon preparing his instruments. "I've been studying that approach shot you struggled with last week. I think if we adjust your stance just slightly and focus on a more controlled follow-through..."

Edmund found himself only half-listening to Marcus's technical observations, instead watching the animated way the younger man gestured when discussing the intricacies of the game. There was something pure about Marcus's enthusiasm, untainted by the political calculations and careful diplomacy that colored every other relationship in Edmund's life. When Marcus looked at him, he saw not a king burdened by centuries of tradition and expectation, but simply a man who loved golf and happened to be rather terrible at it.

"Shall we begin with the driver today?" Marcus asked, selecting the club with a flourish that made Edmund chuckle despite his lingering anxiety.

"By all means. Though I warn you, my form has been even more abysmal than usual lately." Edmund accepted the driver and moved into position, trying to channel the relaxation he felt in Marcus's presence into his swing mechanics.

As he addressed the ball, Edmund became aware of a distant sound that made his blood run cold—the unmistakable quacking of ducks somewhere beyond the tree line that bordered the course. His hands began to shake almost imperceptibly, and he stepped back from the tee with a sharp intake of breath that didn't escape Marcus's notice.

"Everything alright, sir?" Marcus's voice carried genuine concern rather than the performative worry that Edmund had grown accustomed to from his courtiers.

Edmund forced himself to breathe deeply, drawing on techniques his private physician had suggested for managing anxiety attacks. "Quite fine, Marcus. Just... gathering my concentration."

But Marcus had worked with Edmund long enough to recognize the signs of distress, even if he didn't fully understand their cause. Without making a show of it, he positioned himself slightly between Edmund and the direction of the distant sounds, his presence serving as both physical and psychological barrier.

"You know," Marcus said conversationally, "I was reading about Ben Hogan's pre-shot routine the other night. Fascinating fellow, really. He had this way of visualizing each shot in complete detail before he ever addressed the ball. Said it helped him block out all distractions and focus solely on the task at hand."

The gentle redirection worked its intended magic. Edmund found his breathing returning to normal as Marcus continued sharing anecdotes about legendary golfers and their various techniques for maintaining focus under pressure. By the time the distant quacking had faded into silence, Edmund felt sufficiently composed to attempt his opening drive.

The ball soared in a graceful arc down the center of the fairway, coming to rest perhaps thirty yards shorter than Marcus could have managed but representing a respectable effort nonetheless. Marcus's whoop of approval seemed entirely genuine, unmarred by the false enthusiasm that palace staff often employed when addressing their sovereign.

As they walked toward Edmund's ball, their conversation meandered through topics ranging from course maintenance to Marcus's observations about visiting dignitaries who occasionally joined the king for rounds of golf. Edmund found himself genuinely laughing for the first time in weeks as Marcus recounted the previous month's diplomatic incident involving the French ambassador and an unfortunate encounter with a sand trap.

"The poor fellow must have taken twenty strokes getting out of that bunker," Marcus said, mimicking the ambassador's increasingly frantic swing technique. "By the end, he was speaking so rapidly in French that even his translator gave up trying to keep pace."The memory of the ambassador's linguistic meltdown sent Edmund into fresh peals of laughter, the sound echoing across the empty fairway with surprising freedom. It occurred to him that this might be the first time in months he had laughed without immediately censoring himself or worrying about the appropriateness of his reaction. There was something liberating about Marcus's company that stripped away the layers of protocol and performance that typically governed every moment of Edmund's existence. Here, walking across the dew-dampened grass with nothing but the distant hum of groundskeeping equipment for company, he could almost imagine himself as an ordinary man enjoying an ordinary morning with a friend.

Marcus selected a seven iron from the bag and handed it to Edmund with the kind of casual familiarity that would have scandalized the palace staff. No formal presentation of the club, no deferential bow or carefully phrased suggestion—just the easy exchange between two men who had spent countless hours perfecting this particular dance of golfer and caddy. Edmund had initially found such informality jarring, having grown accustomed to the elaborate choreography that surrounded even his most mundane activities. But gradually, Marcus's unpretentious manner had become one of the things he treasured most about their time together.

"Now, remember what we discussed about your grip," Marcus said, moving to stand behind Edmund as he addressed the ball. "Relax those fingers just a touch—you're strangling the poor club like it owes you money. Golf is a game of finesse, not brute force, despite what your natural instincts might tell you."

Edmund made the suggested adjustment, acutely aware of Marcus's proximity as the younger man occasionally reached around to guide his hands into the proper position. These moments of casual physical contact sent unexpected jolts through Edmund's nervous system, sensations he struggled to categorize or understand. It was hardly unusual for servants to assist him with various tasks—his valet helped him dress each morning, his barber trimmed his hair and shaved his face, his physician conducted regular examinations. Yet somehow Marcus's touch felt different, charged with an electricity that had nothing to do with their respective positions in the rigid hierarchy of palace life.

The second shot proved more successful than the first, landing within reasonable distance of the green and drawing another burst of enthusiastic approval from Marcus. As they continued their progress around the course, Edmund found himself studying his companion with new attention to detail. There was grace in the way Marcus moved across the undulating terrain, his steps sure and economical even while carrying the considerable weight of a full golf bag. His hands, Edmund noticed, bore the calluses and slight weathering of someone who worked outdoors, yet they handled the expensive clubs with surprising delicacy. When he spoke about the nuances of the game, his entire demeanor became animated, as though he were discussing not mere sport but something approaching art.

By the seventh hole, Edmund's initial nervousness had largely dissipated, replaced by the familiar rhythm of the game and the comfortable cadence of conversation with Marcus. They had fallen into easy discussion of everything from course design philosophy to Marcus's observations about the changing seasons and their effect on playing conditions. It was the kind of rambling, purposeless talk that Edmund rarely experienced in his official capacity, where every conversation carried weight and consequence, where casual remarks could spark diplomatic incidents or influence matters of state policy.

"I've been wondering," Marcus said as they approached the eighth tee, "about that business dinner you mentioned last week. The one with all the foreign ministers and their elaborate protocol requirements. Do you ever find yourself wishing you could just... escape from it all? Pack a bag and disappear somewhere nobody knows your name or cares about your title?"

The question caught Edmund off guard, not because of its content but because of how accurately it reflected his own increasingly frequent fantasies. How many times in recent months had he found himself staring out his bedroom window, imagining what it might feel like to walk away from Richmond Hill Palace and never look back? To board a ship bound for some distant country where he could reinvent himself as an ordinary citizen, free from the suffocating expectations that had shaped every moment of his thirty-seven years of life.

"The thought has occurred to me," Edmund admitted, surprised by his own honesty. "Though I suspect the reality would prove more challenging than the fantasy. I'm not certain I possess any skills that would prove useful in the common world. My education was rather narrowly focused on matters of statecraft and ceremony, neither of which translates particularly well to practical employment."

Marcus considered this as he selected Edmund's driver, his expression thoughtful rather than dismissive. "I don't know about that, sir. You've got a good eye for reading people, and you're better at listening than most folks give you credit for. Those seem like valuable qualities in any number of professions. Plus, you're learning to play golf, which shows you're not afraid of taking on new challenges even when they don't come naturally."

The casual compliment sent an unexpected warmth through Edmund's chest, a sensation quite different from the formal praise he regularly received from ministers and dignitaries. When Marcus spoke positively about his character or abilities, it felt earned rather than obligatory, based on genuine observation rather than political necessity. Edmund found himself treasuring these small affirmations in ways that probably would have embarrassed him if he'd examined the impulse too closely.The eighth hole presented a particular challenge, with a sharp dogleg that required precise placement to avoid the cluster of ancient oak trees that had been incorporated into the course design. Edmund had struggled with this hole in previous rounds, his natural tendency toward aggressive play often landing him in the rough or worse. Today, however, Marcus suggested a more conservative approach, recommending a five iron that would leave a longer second shot but eliminate the risk of finding the trees.

"Trust the strategy," Marcus said, standing at Edmund's shoulder as the king considered the shot. "Sometimes the brave choice is the patient choice. Those trees have been humbling golfers for three generations—no shame in giving them the respect they deserve."

Edmund executed the shot exactly as planned, watching with satisfaction as the ball came to rest in perfect position for an approach to the green. The success felt sweeter somehow because it represented not just improved technique but also growing trust in Marcus's judgment. In his role as monarch, Edmund was surrounded by advisors whose counsel often served their own interests as much as his. Marcus's guidance, by contrast, seemed motivated purely by a desire to help Edmund improve at something he genuinely enjoyed.

As they walked toward the ball, Edmund found himself thinking about Marcus's earlier question regarding escape and freedom. The young man's perspective on royal life was unlike anything Edmund had encountered before—not the fawning admiration of courtiers, nor the barely concealed resentment of certain political factions, but rather a kind of curious sympathy that suggested Marcus saw the burdens as clearly as the privileges. It was refreshing to be understood in such uncomplicated terms, to have someone acknowledge that power and wealth could not simply dissolve all sources of unhappiness or anxiety.

"May I ask you something rather personal, Marcus?" Edmund said, surprising himself with the impulse toward deeper conversation. "What drew you to this work? I imagine most young men your age have ambitions beyond carrying golf clubs for an aging monarch."

Marcus laughed, the sound carrying genuine amusement rather than the careful deference Edmund had learned to expect from palace staff. "Aging monarch? Your Majesty, you're hardly in your dotage. As for the work—well, I suppose I fell into it rather accidentally. I was studying landscape architecture at university when my father became ill and I needed to find employment quickly. The palace was hiring, and I'd grown up caddying at the local course during summers. It seemed like temporary arrangement, just until I could get back to my studies."

"But you stayed," Edmund observed, selecting the wedge Marcus handed him for his approach shot.

"I stayed," Marcus confirmed, his expression growing more thoughtful. "At first it was just the steady income and the chance to work outdoors. But then I realized I genuinely enjoyed the game itself—not just playing it, but understanding it. Golf is endlessly complex, you know. Every shot is influenced by wind, lie, pin position, course conditions. It's like solving a new puzzle eighteen times each round. And working with different players, helping them improve their game, watching that moment when something clicks and they execute a shot they've been struggling with for months—there's real satisfaction in that."

Edmund lined up his approach shot, finding himself oddly moved by Marcus's passion for what many would consider menial work. There was dignity in the younger man's commitment to excellence, regardless of whether anyone else recognized or valued his expertise. The wedge shot flew true, landing softly on the green and rolling to within ten feet of the pin—one of Edmund's finest approaches in recent memory.

"Outstanding!" Marcus exclaimed, his enthusiasm infectious. "That's exactly the tempo we've been working toward. Smooth acceleration through the ball, perfect trajectory control."

The praise felt like a small triumph, made more meaningful by the knowledge that it was entirely unrelated to Edmund's status or position. Marcus celebrated his golf shots based purely on their technical merit, creating a space where Edmund could experience genuine accomplishment independent of royal obligation. As they walked onto the green, Edmund found himself wondering if this was what normal friendship felt like—this easy exchange of conversation and shared activity, unmarked by the complex calculations that governed most of his personal relationships.

The putt required careful reading, as the green sloped subtly toward a small pond that bordered the eighth hole. Edmund studied the line while Marcus held the flagstick, their routine so well-established by now that they moved in perfect coordination without need for explicit communication. The ball rolled smoothly across the closely cropped grass, catching the left edge of the cup and dropping with a satisfying rattle that sent a surge of genuine joy through Edmund's chest.

"Birdie!" Marcus announced, grinning as he retrieved the ball from the cup. "Your best score on this hole by at least two strokes. That approach shot made all the difference—perfect club selection and execution."

As they moved toward the ninth tee, Edmund realized that somewhere during the past hour, his earlier anxiety had completely dissolved. The distant memory of ducks and the familiar weight of royal responsibility seemed to belong to some other person's experience. Here, in Marcus's company, surrounded by the peaceful geometry of fairways and greens, he felt more like himself than he had in months. The sensation was both exhilarating and slightly terrifying, suggesting as it did how constrained and artificial his normal existence had become.

The ninth hole offered a spectacular view of the surrounding countryside, with rolling hills stretching toward the horizon and the spires of distant villages visible through gaps in the tree line. Edmund had always found this particular vantage point soothing, a reminder that the world extended far beyond the confines of palace walls and political intrigue. Today, sharing the view with Marcus, the landscape seemed even more beautiful, as though seeing it through someone else's eyes had somehow enhanced its natural majesty.

"I used to think I might like to be a painter," Marcus said quietly, following Edmund's gaze across the vista. "Back when I was younger and thought artistic talent was something you could simply decide to possess. I'd sit in places like this and imagine how I might capture all those layers of color and light, the way the morning mist clings to the valleys. Never had the skill for it, of course, but I still appreciate the beauty."

Edmund turned to study Marcus's profile as the younger man gazed across the countryside, noting the genuine appreciation in his expression and the slight wistfulness in his voice when he spoke of abandoned dreams. There was something deeply appealing about Marcus's willingness to acknowledge both desire and limitation without bitterness or self-pity. It suggested a kind of emotional maturity that Edmund found increasingly rare in his experience.

"Perhaps you still could," Edmund said, the words emerging before he had fully considered their implications. "Learn to paint, I mean. It's hardly too late—you're still quite young, and artistic ability can be developed with proper instruction and practice."

Marcus smiled, but there was something complex in the expression that Edmund couldn't quite interpret. "That's kind of you to say, Your Majesty. Though I suspect my current circumstances make such pursuits rather impractical. Artistic development requires time and resources I don't particularly possess."

The response carried subtle implications that Edmund found himself wanting to explore, though he sensed the conversation was approaching territory that might prove delicate. There was clearly much about Marcus's background and personal situation that remained unknown to him, despite the easy familiarity they had developed over months of regular golf outings. Edmund realized that most of their conversations had focused on the immediate present—golf technique, course conditions, amusing anecdotes from recent palace events—without delving deeply into Marcus's past or future aspirations.**Chapter 2**

The back nine proved more challenging than Edmund had anticipated, not due to the course conditions but because of a growing awareness that his time with Marcus was approaching its natural conclusion. Each successive hole brought them closer to the eighteenth green, and with it, the return to palace routine that would separate them until their next scheduled round. This mounting sense of impending loss puzzled Edmund, as he had never before experienced such reluctance to conclude a recreational activity. Golf had always been a pleasant diversion from royal duties, but now it had become something more precious—a sanctuary where he could exist as simply himself, unburdened by the weight of crown and expectation.

Marcus seemed to sense Edmund's shifting mood, though he attributed it to frustration with a series of wayward shots that had cost the king several strokes on holes ten and eleven. The younger man redoubled his efforts to provide technical guidance and encouragement, his voice taking on the patient tone of someone accustomed to helping struggling players work through temporary setbacks. What Marcus couldn't have known was that Edmund's deteriorating play had nothing to do with mechanical problems and everything to do with his growing preoccupation with their approaching separation.

"Your tempo's gotten a bit quick," Marcus observed as they walked toward Edmund's ball on the twelfth fairway. The shot had pulled badly left, finding the rough beneath a stand of birch trees that would complicate the approach to the green. "It happens to everyone when they start thinking too hard about score instead of just playing each shot as it comes. Let's focus on getting good contact with this recovery shot rather than trying to be perfect."

Edmund nodded absently, accepting Marcus's analysis even though he knew the real source of his distraction lay elsewhere entirely. The younger man's proximity as he helped line up the difficult lie sent familiar jolts of electricity through Edmund's nervous system, sensations that were becoming increasingly difficult to dismiss or rationalize. When Marcus reached around him to adjust his grip on the seven iron, Edmund found himself acutely conscious of the warmth radiating from the other man's body and the faint scent of his cologne mingling with fresh morning air.

The recovery shot came off better than either of them had expected, the ball flying cleanly through a gap in the branches and landing just short of the green. Marcus's whoop of approval seemed especially enthusiastic, as though he understood how much Edmund needed encouragement at this particular moment. As they walked together toward the putting surface, Edmund found himself studying the animated way Marcus gestured while describing the technical aspects of the shot, his hands moving in fluid arcs that somehow made the complex physics of ball flight seem like poetry.

"That's the shot of the day right there," Marcus declared, setting down the golf bag with a flourish. "Perfect club selection for a difficult lie, and you kept your head still through the entire swing. Sometimes the best golf happens when you stop trying so hard and just trust your instincts."

The compliment sent warmth flooding through Edmund's chest, made more meaningful by his growing certainty that Marcus's praise was entirely genuine, unmarked by the calculated flattery he had learned to expect from courtiers and ministers. Here was someone who celebrated his small triumphs based purely on their merit, who offered criticism and guidance without ulterior motive, who seemed to value his company for reasons entirely unconnected to political advantage or royal favor. The realization was both exhilarating and deeply unsettling, suggesting as it did how rarely Edmund experienced such uncomplicated human connection.

The thirteenth hole featured a particularly challenging green, its surface undulating in ways that had confounded golfers since the course's original design. Edmund had never successfully read the complex breaks and slopes, usually requiring at least three putts to find the hole from any significant distance. Today, however, Marcus spent extra time helping him analyze the subtle gradients and grain patterns, his instruction more detailed and patient than usual, as though he too wanted to extend their time together on the course.

"See how the grass has a slightly different color along that ridge?" Marcus pointed toward a barely perceptible change in the green's surface texture. "That indicates the grain direction, which will affect how much the ball breaks as it loses speed. Most players only pay attention to the obvious slopes, but reading grain is what separates good putters from great ones."

Edmund followed Marcus's finger, squinting to discern the subtle variations in grass color and texture that the younger man identified with such apparent ease. The level of detailed observation required suggested years of careful study, a dedication to craft that Edmund found unexpectedly moving. Here was someone who had taken what others might consider mundane work and elevated it through genuine expertise and passionate attention to detail. The respect Edmund felt for such commitment surprised him with its intensity.

Under Marcus's patient guidance, Edmund managed to sink the fifteen-foot putt on his second attempt, the ball rolling smoothly across the complex surface and disappearing into the cup with satisfying finality. The success felt like a minor miracle, achieved through trust in Marcus's reading of conditions that Edmund's less experienced eye had completely failed to detect. As they walked toward the fourteenth tee, Edmund found himself wondering how many other aspects of life might benefit from such careful observation and expert guidance.

"I've been thinking about what you said earlier," Edmund ventured as Marcus selected the appropriate driver for the upcoming hole. "Regarding artistic pursuits and the practical limitations you mentioned. I wonder if perhaps those constraints are less absolute than they might appear."

Marcus paused in his club selection, his expression growing thoughtful as he considered Edmund's words. "That's generous of you to say, Your Majesty, though I suspect you might underestimate the realities of my situation. Artistic instruction requires both time and money, neither of which are particularly abundant in my current circumstances. Between this position and helping support my mother since my father's passing, there isn't much room for personal indulgences."

The revelation of family responsibility and financial constraint struck Edmund with unexpected force, highlighting the vast gulf between their respective circumstances in ways that their easy companionship had temporarily obscured. While Edmund worried about ceremonial obligations and diplomatic protocol, Marcus dealt with genuine economic pressures and personal sacrifice. The contrast was both humbling and oddly attractive, suggesting depths of character forged by real-world challenges that Edmund's privileged existence had never required him to face.

"I had no idea about your father," Edmund said quietly, accepting the driver Marcus offered while processing this new information about the younger man's background. "Please accept my condolences on your loss. It speaks well of your character that you've taken on such family responsibilities, though I'm sorry the burden has required you to set aside personal ambitions."

Marcus's smile carried gratitude mixed with something more complex that Edmund couldn't quite identify. "Thank you, sir. He was a good man—worked as a groundskeeper for the county council until his health began failing. Taught me to appreciate outdoor work and take pride in doing any job well, regardless of how others might value it. I like to think he'd approve of how I've tried to honor those lessons."

The simple dignity of Marcus's response stirred something deep in Edmund's chest, an emotion that seemed to combine admiration, affection, and an unexpected protectiveness toward this young man who carried his responsibilities with such grace. Edmund found himself wanting to know more about Marcus's father, about the family circumstances that had shaped his character, about the dreams he had sacrificed for duty to others. The intensity of this curiosity surprised him, suggesting a level of personal interest that went well beyond casual conversation between employer and employee.

Edmund's tee shot on fourteen flew straight and true, one of his longest drives of the round, though he barely registered the technical success. His attention remained focused on Marcus, on the way afternoon sunlight caught the golden highlights in his sandy hair, on the easy confidence with which he moved across terrain he knew intimately, on the genuine warmth in his voice when he spoke of family and responsibility. These observations felt simultaneously natural and dangerous, touching on feelings that Edmund struggled to categorize or understand.

As they walked down the fourway together, their conversation meandered through topics both serious and lighthearted—Marcus's memories of learning golf from the old Scottish professional who had taught at the local course, Edmund's frustrations with recent trade negotiations that seemed to consume endless hours while producing minimal progress, shared observations about the changing seasons and their effect on course conditions. The easy flow of dialogue continued to amaze Edmund, representing the kind of natural human connection that his royal position typically precluded.

"May I ask you something rather forward?" Edmund said as they approached his ball, surprising himself with the boldness of the question forming in his mind. "Do you ever feel constrained by the formal nature of your position here? The protocols and boundaries that govern how we interact?"

Marcus stopped walking, his expression growing more serious as he considered the implications of Edmund's inquiry. "I suppose I do, sometimes," he admitted after a moment's reflection. "There are certainly things I might say or do differently if circumstances were... different. But I try to focus on what is possible within the current arrangement rather than dwelling on limitations. Why do you ask, if you don't mind my curiosity?"

The directness of Marcus's counter-question caught Edmund off guard, forcing him to examine motivations he wasn't entirely ready to acknowledge. Why had he asked? What was he hoping to accomplish with such a line of inquiry? The honest answer involved feelings and desires that Edmund wasn't prepared to articulate, even to himself, much less to the object of those increasingly complex emotions.

"I find myself wondering about authentic connection," Edmund said carefully, choosing words that felt truthful without being dangerously revealing. "So much of my interaction with others is constrained by ceremony and expectation that I sometimes lose track of what genuine friendship might feel like. Our time together on the course represents one of the few contexts where I feel... more like myself, I suppose."

Marcus nodded slowly, his expression conveying understanding mixed with what might have been sympathy. "I can imagine that would be difficult, having every relationship filtered through political considerations and formal protocol. For what it's worth, sir, I've always felt that our conversations here have been refreshingly honest compared to most interactions within palace walls. You seem more relaxed when you're focused on golf, less burdened by whatever obligations typically occupy your thoughts."

The observation was both perceptive and affirming, confirming Edmund's own sense that something special existed between them during these stolen hours on the course. Marcus had noticed the same transformation that Edmund experienced, the gradual shedding of royal persona in favor of something more authentic and spontaneous. The mutual recognition of this shift felt significant, though Edmund wasn't certain what implications it might carry for their future interactions.

His approach shot on fourteen landed safely on the green, though well short of the pin placement. As they walked together across the closely cropped surface, Edmund found himself hoping that the round would somehow extend indefinitely, that they might continue walking and talking without ever reaching the final hole. The afternoon sun had begun its gradual descent toward the horizon, painting the landscape in warmer hues that made everything seem touched with golden possibility. In this perfect moment, surrounded by natural beauty and accompanied by someone whose presence had become unexpectedly precious, Edmund could almost forget about the complex web of duty and obligation that awaited his return to palace life.

The putt required two attempts, but Marcus celebrated the eventual success with characteristic enthusiasm, his approval warming Edmund more than any official commendation he had received in recent memory. As they prepared to leave the green, Edmund caught Marcus watching him with an expression he couldn't quite interpret—something thoughtful and perhaps slightly wistful, as though the younger man was also experiencing reluctance about their approaching separation.**Chapter 3**

The fifteenth hole stretched before them like a verdant amphitheater, its elevated tee providing panoramic views of the palace grounds that Edmund had admired countless times throughout his life. Today, however, the familiar landscape seemed transformed by Marcus's presence beside him, as though seeing it through the younger man's appreciative eyes had somehow enhanced its natural beauty. The afternoon light cast everything in warm amber tones that made the rolling fairways appear almost ethereal, and Edmund found himself reluctant to break the spell by actually playing the hole that would bring them three steps closer to the end of their round.

Marcus had grown quieter as they progressed through the back nine, though his instruction and encouragement remained as attentive as ever. Edmund sensed a subtle shift in the younger man's demeanor, a thoughtfulness that suggested he too was processing the implications of their earlier conversation about authenticity and connection. When their eyes met during the natural pauses between shots, Edmund detected something new in Marcus's gaze—a warmth that seemed to extend beyond professional courtesy or even casual friendship, touching on depths that neither of them had previously acknowledged.

"This hole always reminds me of a painting I saw once in London," Marcus said, breaking the comfortable silence that had settled between them. "A landscape by Constable, I believe, though I'm hardly an expert on such matters. Something about the way the light falls across those distant hills and catches in the tree lines. Makes you understand why artists spend their lives trying to capture moments like this on canvas."

Edmund followed Marcus's gaze across the sweeping vista, noting how the younger man's profile was softened by the golden afternoon light. There was something almost sculptural about the clean lines of his jaw and the gentle curve of his mouth as he spoke, qualities that Edmund found himself cataloging with an artist's attention to detail despite having no artistic training whatsoever. The realization that he was studying Marcus's physical features with such concentrated interest sent a flutter of anxiety through his chest, suggesting emotions and desires that he wasn't prepared to examine too closely.

"Perhaps you should reconsider pursuing that artistic instruction we discussed," Edmund said, his voice carrying more intensity than he had intended. "I meant what I said earlier about practical constraints being less absolute than they might appear. There are ways such obstacles could be... addressed, if the desire for learning were genuine enough."

Marcus turned to face him fully, his expression growing serious as he searched Edmund's face for the meaning behind such a generous offer. "Your Majesty, I appreciate the thought more than I can express, but I couldn't possibly accept that kind of assistance. The financial implications alone would be inappropriate, given our respective positions. And besides, I'm not certain I have any real talent to develop. Childhood dreams and adult capabilities are often quite different things."

The gentle rejection stung more than Edmund had expected, though he recognized the wisdom in Marcus's concerns about propriety and professional boundaries. Still, the younger man's immediate assumption that such help would be inappropriate highlighted the social gulf between them in ways that their easy companionship had temporarily allowed Edmund to forget. Here was a reminder that despite their growing connection, they remained separated by centuries of tradition and expectation that governed every aspect of royal interaction with commoners.

Edmund's drive on fifteen sailed cleanly down the center of the fairway, though he barely registered the technical success of the shot. His mind remained focused on the complex emotions stirred by Marcus's polite refusal of assistance, and the growing certainty that his feelings for the younger man had evolved far beyond simple friendship or professional appreciation. The intensity of his desire to help Marcus pursue artistic dreams, to remove obstacles from his path, to see him flourish and succeed—these impulses suggested depths of caring that Edmund found both exhilarating and terrifying.

As they walked together down the fairway, their conversation returned to safer topics like course conditions and strategy for the remaining holes. But beneath the familiar rhythm of their golf-focused dialogue, Edmund sensed new undercurrents of tension and possibility that neither of them seemed ready to address directly. When Marcus handed him clubs or offered technical advice, their brief physical contact carried electric charges that left Edmund's skin tingling and his pulse elevated. The younger man seemed equally affected by these moments of proximity, though he maintained his professional demeanor with admirable consistency.

The approach shot on fifteen required careful calculation due to a tricky pin placement that threatened to send overly aggressive attempts rolling off the back of the green. Marcus spent extra time helping Edmund read the wind conditions and select the appropriate club, their consultation extending longer than strictly necessary as though both men were reluctant to conclude even this minor interaction. When Marcus positioned himself behind Edmund to check his alignment, the younger man's breath against his neck sent shivers through Edmund's entire nervous system, sensations so intense that he nearly stepped away from the ball to compose himself.

The morning sun cast long shadows across the manicured lawns of Richmond Hill Palace, where King Edmund Fairweather III stood at his bedroom window, gripping the silk curtains with trembling fingers. Below in the ornamental pond, a family of mallards glided serenely across the water's surface, their movements sending ripples that caught the light like scattered diamonds. What should have been a peaceful scene instead filled the monarch with a dread so profound that sweat beaded on his brow despite the cool autumn air.

It had begun three months ago during a state dinner with the Danish ambassador. A decorative centerpiece featuring carved wooden ducks had somehow triggered something primal within him—a fear so intense and irrational that he'd excused himself mid-conversation and spent the remainder of the evening locked in his private study. Since that mortifying evening, the phobia had only grown stronger, spreading like ivy across every aspect of his carefully ordered life.

Edmund's valet, Reginald, entered the chamber carrying the morning papers and a silver tray laden with Earl Grey tea and buttered scones. The elderly man had served three generations of Fairweather kings and possessed an uncanny ability to sense his master's moods before they fully manifested themselves.

"Your Majesty appears troubled this morning," Reginald observed, setting the tray on the mahogany side table with practiced precision. "Perhaps a round of golf might prove beneficial? The weather is quite agreeable, and I believe your caddy Marcus mentioned something about perfecting your sand wedge technique."

The suggestion of golf brought the first genuine smile to Edmund's lips in days. The sprawling eighteen-hole course at Richmond Hill represented one of the few places where he could find respite from the crushing weight of royal obligations and the ever-present anxiety that now plagued his waking hours. More importantly, it meant spending time with Marcus Hartwell, the young man whose easy laughter and unpretentious manner had become something of an anchor in Edmund's increasingly turbulent world.

"An excellent suggestion, Reginald. Please inform Marcus that we'll tee off at nine o'clock sharp." Edmund turned from the window, deliberately avoiding another glance at the pond below. "And see that the groundskeepers have cleared the course of any... waterfowl."

The older man's expression remained diplomatically neutral, though Edmund caught a flicker of something—concern, perhaps, or pity—in his weathered features. Word of the king's unusual affliction had inevitably spread throughout the palace staff, despite Edmund's efforts to maintain discretion. While most of his servants remained respectfully silent about their master's condition, he was acutely aware of the whispered conversations that ceased whenever he entered a room.

An hour later, Edmund found himself on the first tee, inhaling the familiar scents of freshly cut grass and morning dew. The golf course stretched before him like a verdant tapestry, its rolling hills and strategic sand traps designed by some long-forgotten Scottish master. Here, surrounded by the gentle undulations of perfectly maintained fairways, the king could almost forget about the weight of the crown and the growing chorus of critics who questioned his fitness to rule.

Marcus Hartwell approached with the golf bag slung over his shoulder, his sandy hair tousled by the breeze and his face brightened by that characteristic grin that never failed to lift Edmund's spirits. At twenty-eight, Marcus was nearly a decade younger than the king, with the lean build of someone who spent his days walking miles across challenging terrain. He'd been working as Edmund's personal caddy for two years now, ever since the previous caddy had retired to tend his garden in the Cotswolds.

"Lovely morning for a round, Your Majesty," Marcus said, beginning his ritual of cleaning and arranging the clubs with the methodical care of a surgeon preparing his instruments. "I've been studying that approach shot you struggled with last week. I think if we adjust your stance just slightly and focus on a more controlled follow-through..."

Edmund found himself only half-listening to Marcus's technical observations, instead watching the animated way the younger man gestured when discussing the intricacies of the game. There was something pure about Marcus's enthusiasm, untainted by the political calculations and careful diplomacy that colored every other relationship in Edmund's life. When Marcus looked at him, he saw not a king burdened by centuries of tradition and expectation, but simply a man who loved golf and happened to be rather terrible at it.

"Shall we begin with the driver today?" Marcus asked, selecting the club with a flourish that made Edmund chuckle despite his lingering anxiety.

"By all means. Though I warn you, my form has been even more abysmal than usual lately." Edmund accepted the driver and moved into position, trying to channel the relaxation he felt in Marcus's presence into his swing mechanics.

As he addressed the ball, Edmund became aware of a distant sound that made his blood run cold—the unmistakable quacking of ducks somewhere beyond the tree line that bordered the course. His hands began to shake almost imperceptibly, and he stepped back from the tee with a sharp intake of breath that didn't escape Marcus's notice.

"Everything alright, sir?" Marcus's voice carried genuine concern rather than the performative worry that Edmund had grown accustomed to from his courtiers.

Edmund forced himself to breathe deeply, drawing on techniques his private physician had suggested for managing anxiety attacks. "Quite fine, Marcus. Just... gathering my concentration."

But Marcus had worked with Edmund long enough to recognize the signs of distress, even if he didn't fully understand their cause. Without making a show of it, he positioned himself slightly between Edmund and the direction of the distant sounds, his presence serving as both physical and psychological barrier.

"You know," Marcus said conversationally, "I was reading about Ben Hogan's pre-shot routine the other night. Fascinating fellow, really. He had this way of visualizing each shot in complete detail before he ever addressed the ball. Said it helped him block out all distractions and focus solely on the task at hand."

The gentle redirection worked its intended magic. Edmund found his breathing returning to normal as Marcus continued sharing anecdotes about legendary golfers and their various techniques for maintaining focus under pressure. By the time the distant quacking had faded into silence, Edmund felt sufficiently composed to attempt his opening drive.

The ball soared in a graceful arc down the center of the fairway, coming to rest perhaps thirty yards shorter than Marcus could have managed but representing a respectable effort nonetheless. Marcus's whoop of approval seemed entirely genuine, unmarred by the false enthusiasm that palace staff often employed when addressing their sovereign.

As they walked toward Edmund's ball, their conversation meandered through topics ranging from course maintenance to Marcus's observations about visiting dignitaries who occasionally joined the king for rounds of golf. Edmund found himself genuinely laughing for the first time in weeks as Marcus recounted the previous month's diplomatic incident involving the French ambassador and an unfortunate encounter with a sand trap.

"The poor fellow must have taken twenty strokes getting out of that bunker," Marcus said, mimicking the ambassador's increasingly frantic swing technique. "By the end, he was speaking so rapidly in French that even his translator gave up trying to keep pace."

The memory of the ambassador's linguistic meltdown sent Edmund into fresh peals of laughter, the sound echoing across the empty fairway with surprising freedom. It occurred to him that this might be the first time in months he had laughed without immediately censoring himself or worrying about the appropriateness of his reaction. There was something liberating about Marcus's company that stripped away the layers of protocol and performance that typically governed every moment of Edmund's existence. Here, walking across the dew-dampened grass with nothing but the distant hum of groundskeeping equipment for company, he could almost imagine himself as an ordinary man enjoying an ordinary morning with a friend.

Marcus selected a seven iron from the bag and handed it to Edmund with the kind of casual familiarity that would have scandalized the palace staff. No formal presentation of the club, no deferential bow or carefully phrased suggestion—just the easy exchange between two men who had spent countless hours perfecting this particular dance of golfer and caddy. Edmund had initially found such informality jarring, having grown accustomed to the elaborate choreography that surrounded even his most mundane activities. But gradually, Marcus's unpretentious manner had become one of the things he treasured most about their time together.

"Now, remember what we discussed about your grip," Marcus said, moving to stand behind Edmund as he addressed the ball. "Relax those fingers just a touch—you're strangling the poor club like it owes you money. Golf is a game of finesse, not brute force, despite what your natural instincts might tell you."

Edmund made the suggested adjustment, acutely aware of Marcus's proximity as the younger man occasionally reached around to guide his hands into the proper position. These moments of casual physical contact sent unexpected jolts through Edmund's nervous system, sensations he struggled to categorize or understand. It was hardly unusual for servants to assist him with various tasks—his valet helped him dress each morning, his barber trimmed his hair and shaved his face, his physician conducted regular examinations. Yet somehow Marcus's touch felt different, charged with an electricity that had nothing to do with their respective positions in the rigid hierarchy of palace life.

The second shot proved more successful than the first, landing within reasonable distance of the green and drawing another burst of enthusiastic approval from Marcus. As they continued their progress around the course, Edmund found himself studying his companion with new attention to detail. There was grace in the way Marcus moved across the undulating terrain, his steps sure and economical even while carrying the considerable weight of a full golf bag. His hands, Edmund noticed, bore the calluses and slight weathering of someone who worked outdoors, yet they handled the expensive clubs with surprising delicacy. When he spoke about the nuances of the game, his entire demeanor became animated, as though he were discussing not mere sport but something approaching art.

By the seventh hole, Edmund's initial nervousness had largely dissipated, replaced by the familiar rhythm of the game and the comfortable cadence of conversation with Marcus. They had fallen into easy discussion of everything from course design philosophy to Marcus's observations about the changing seasons and their effect on playing conditions. It was the kind of rambling, purposeless talk that Edmund rarely experienced in his official capacity, where every conversation carried weight and consequence, where casual remarks could spark diplomatic incidents or influence matters of state policy.

"I've been wondering," Marcus said as they approached the eighth tee, "about that business dinner you mentioned last week. The one with all the foreign ministers and their elaborate protocol requirements. Do you ever find yourself wishing you could just... escape from it all? Pack a bag and disappear somewhere nobody knows your name or cares about your title?"

The question caught Edmund off guard, not because of its content but because of how accurately it reflected his own increasingly frequent fantasies. How many times in recent months had he found himself staring out his bedroom window, imagining what it might feel like to walk away from Richmond Hill Palace and never look back? To board a ship bound for some distant country where he could reinvent himself as an ordinary citizen, free from the suffocating expectations that had shaped every moment of his thirty-seven years of life.

"The thought has occurred to me," Edmund admitted, surprised by his own honesty. "Though I suspect the reality would prove more challenging than the fantasy. I'm not certain I possess any skills that would prove useful in the common world. My education was rather narrowly focused on matters of statecraft and ceremony, neither of which translates particularly well to practical employment."

Marcus considered this as he selected Edmund's driver, his expression thoughtful rather than dismissive. "I don't know about that, sir. You've got a good eye for reading people, and you're better at listening than most folks give you credit for. Those seem like valuable qualities in any number of professions. Plus, you're learning to play golf, which shows you're not afraid of taking on new challenges even when they don't come naturally."

The casual compliment sent an unexpected warmth through Edmund's chest, a sensation quite different from the formal praise he regularly received from ministers and dignitaries. When Marcus spoke positively about his character or abilities, it felt earned rather than obligatory, based on genuine observation rather than political necessity. Edmund found himself treasuring these small affirmations in ways that probably would have embarrassed him if he'd examined the impulse too closely.

The eighth hole presented a particular challenge, with a sharp dogleg that required precise placement to avoid the cluster of ancient oak trees that had been incorporated into the course design. Edmund had struggled with this hole in previous rounds, his natural tendency toward aggressive play often landing him in the rough or worse. Today, however, Marcus suggested a more conservative approach, recommending a five iron that would leave a longer second shot but eliminate the risk of finding the trees.

"Trust the strategy," Marcus said, standing at Edmund's shoulder as the king considered the shot. "Sometimes the brave choice is the patient choice. Those trees have been humbling golfers for three generations—no shame in giving them the respect they deserve."

Edmund executed the shot exactly as planned, watching with satisfaction as the ball came to rest in perfect position for an approach to the green. The success felt sweeter somehow because it represented not just improved technique but also growing trust in Marcus's judgment. In his role as monarch, Edmund was surrounded by advisors whose counsel often served their own interests as much as his. Marcus's guidance, by contrast, seemed motivated purely by a desire to help Edmund improve at something he genuinely enjoyed.

As they walked toward the ball, Edmund found himself thinking about Marcus's earlier question regarding escape and freedom. The young man's perspective on royal life was unlike anything Edmund had encountered before—not the fawning admiration of courtiers, nor the barely concealed resentment of certain political factions, but rather a kind of curious sympathy that suggested Marcus saw the burdens as clearly as the privileges. It was refreshing to be understood in such uncomplicated terms, to have someone acknowledge that power and wealth could not simply dissolve all sources of unhappiness or anxiety.

"May I ask you something rather personal, Marcus?" Edmund said, surprising himself with the impulse toward deeper conversation. "What drew you to this work? I imagine most young men your age have ambitions beyond carrying golf clubs for an aging monarch."

Marcus laughed, the sound carrying genuine amusement rather than the careful deference Edmund had learned to expect from palace staff. "Aging monarch? Your Majesty, you're hardly in your dotage. As for the work—well, I suppose I fell into it rather accidentally. I was studying landscape architecture at university when my father became ill and I needed to find employment quickly. The palace was hiring, and I'd grown up caddying at the local course during summers. It seemed like temporary arrangement, just until I could get back to my studies."

"But you stayed," Edmund observed, selecting the wedge Marcus handed him for his approach shot.

"I stayed," Marcus confirmed, his expression growing more thoughtful. "At first it was just the steady income and the chance to work outdoors. But then I realized I genuinely enjoyed the game itself—not just playing it, but understanding it. Golf is endlessly complex, you know. Every shot is influenced by wind, lie, pin position, course conditions. It's like solving a new puzzle eighteen times each round. And working with different players, helping them improve their game, watching that moment when something clicks and they execute a shot they've been struggling with for months—there's real satisfaction in that."

Edmund lined up his approach shot, finding himself oddly moved by Marcus's passion for what many would consider menial work. There was dignity in the younger man's commitment to excellence, regardless of whether anyone else recognized or valued his expertise. The wedge shot flew true, landing softly on the green and rolling to within ten feet of the pin—one of Edmund's finest approaches in recent memory.

"Outstanding!" Marcus exclaimed, his enthusiasm infectious. "That's exactly the tempo we've been working toward. Smooth acceleration through the ball, perfect trajectory control."

The praise felt like a small triumph, made more meaningful by the knowledge that it was entirely unrelated to Edmund's status or position. Marcus celebrated his golf shots based purely on their technical merit, creating a space where Edmund could experience genuine accomplishment independent of royal obligation. As they walked onto the green, Edmund found himself wondering if this was what normal friendship felt like—this easy exchange of conversation and shared activity, unmarked by the complex calculations that governed most of his personal relationships.
